Presenting the final lecture in

Dr. Jacob H. Hollander, Professor of Political Economy at the
Hopkins, discussed t'he recent action of Great Britain concerning
the gold standard.
Dr. Hollander divided the history of his subject into four parts.
His discussion of them follows :
First Period From 1821-1914
"The first begins in 1821 when
after t~nty-four years of sus;

the strain of the Napoleonic struggle, the Bank of England i·esumed
the free conversion of its notes into
gold. This continued the firm unvarying practice of England until
the outbreak of the World War
in 1914. During this long period
from 1821 to 1914 the rest of the
civilized world, iniluenced largely
by England's example, swung successively into the gold line. Currency systems based on inconvertible paper, on silver, on gold and
silver joined in a bimetallic ratio,
were reconstructed until at the
close of the period the whole civilized world, with a few unimportant exceptions, was transacting its
domestic exchanges and discharging its international balances with
the aid of a gold measure of value.
"With the outbreak of the World
War the gold standard was promptly abandoned by all countries and
an era of inconvertible paper introduced. Gold was impounded and
hoarded, and government printing
presses were used to fill the gap.
The result was over-issue, inflation,
and depreciation to a considerable
extent during hostilities, but to a
much grosser degree after the
Armistice. This decade may fairly
be described as the dark age of
currency history.
England Courageous
"In 1925 England led the van, as
a century before, in the restoration
of the gold standard. By a costly
process of contracting the outstanding paper anl of building up
a gold reserve, England, with perhaps greater courage than wisdom,
resumed the exchange of note
issues for gold at the old rate.
Other countries were less 'sturdy.
In Rusia, Germany and Austria the
paper money had sunk into worthlessness; repudiation was frankly
accepted 'and a fresh start made.
In France, Belgium and Italy a
go)d standa~d was i·estored but on
a devalued base corresponding to
the current depreciation.
"The fourth period, of which the
end is not in sight, was ushered in
by the English suspension of September 21, 1931. The act wias
precipitated by the tottering of
important financial institutions in
central Europe and by the disclosures of the May Report in England that drastic fiscal retrenchment and heavier taxation were
imperative budget requirements.
The confidence of foreign creditors
and to some extent of English
capitalists was shaken, and a drain
of gold began which neither
courageous action nor extensive
credits could stop As a French
critic somewhat sardonically remarked, "The pound sterling died
